g.text: applications. As a result, much effort has been devoted to the development of lead-free or lead-reduced halide
perovskites with suitable band gaps that are capable of preserving their optoelectronic properties by incorporating
. In this regard, the synthesis of lead-free perovskites using the tin (Sn
cation with a potential application in solar cells has been demonstrated primarily, however, their poorer stability,
smaller bandgap, and intrinsic defects yielding a low PLQY discourage further applications
3.6 eV) was found to be too large to
serve as photon down-conversion materials in WLEDs
. The lead-free double perovskites with A
(where â€˜Bâ€™ is a monovalent cation and â€˜B
â€™ is a trivalent cation) were also proposed as a candidate for the appli-
. These compounds have good stability, suitable bandgap energy, and are
. However, the double perovskites tend to have an indirect bandgap, which is not favorable
for the applications in optoelectronic devices
The incorporation of the homovalent or heterovalent metal cations at the B-site of halide perovskites to par-
cations has also been explored as an alternative approach to reducing the toxicity of lead
. Recently, we reported the synthesis of lead-reduced CsPb
20%) NCs for the fabrication of the WLEDs
. Our experimental results showed that the as-synthesized
NCs retained the superior optical properties and these NCs have been utilized to fabricate WLEDs with superior
color quality. Partial replacement of Pb
in lead halide perovskites and their potential applications
in photovoltaic cells have been demonstrated
. Besides the reduction of lead content, the as-fabricated solar
cells resulted in enhanced thermal stability and improved photovoltaic performance of the device structure. The
partial substitution of the reduced B-site cations (compared to Pb
) such as the transition metal ions can reduce
the size of eight cubo-octahedral voids which has the potential to decrease all of the cubo-octahedral voids for
lattice. This results in a stable perovskite phase with superior thermal stability
. observed that the application of Zn
NCs as a light emitter resulted in an
LED with a peak external quantum efficiency of 15.1%
. However, there is no report on the fabrication of WLEDs
In this work, the comprehensive studies are carried out to investigate the effect of Zn
tural and optical properties of CsZn
NCs (x up to 15%). The ultimate goal of this work is to realize
the low-cost, highly efficient, and environmental-friendly white light with superior color quality. The inclusion
NCs results in a lattice contraction, however, the NCs maintain identical crystal
structure and the morphology. The as-grown NCs exhibit strong photoluminescence (PL) emissions that are
content because of the reduced size of unit cells while maintaining the high
). In addition, the tunable bandgap from 1.82 eV
to 3.19 eV and tunable emission from 411 nm to 636 nm are obtained by engineering the halide compositions
inclusion. Furthermore, the prototype WLEDs based on CsZn
experimentally demonstrated by stacking the Zn
-alloyed blue-, green-, yellow-, and red-emitting NCs on top
of a UV LED. The WLEDs emit white light with a tunable CCT from warm to cold (2218â€“8335 K). In addition,
an extra high CRI (maximized to 93) and high LER (268â€“318 lmÂ·W
) are achieved which is superior to the pre-
vious studies on WLEDs based on metal halide perovskites doped with other transition metals. Thus, this work
opens up new prospects to engineer the properties of compositionally diverse lead-reduced halide perovskite NCs
potentially to be used in lighting technology.
-alloying on the Structural, Morphological, and optical properties of csZn
The effect of the inclusion of Zn
on the structural property of CsPbCl
is investigated by measuring the XRD patterns. The XRD patterns of CsZn
) for the different concentrations of Zn
confirm that the NCs have cubic structure and the
content. The main diffraction peaks are at
ing to the (100), (110), (200), and (211) diffraction planes of the cubic crystal structure, respectively. However,
there is some evidence that the structure of the CsPbCl
NCs exhibit an orthorhombic phase at the
. The opposed orthorhombic subdomains of the NCs annihilate their superstructural peaks leading
to a perceived cubic phase that is in reality pseudocubic. As shown in Fig.Â
appears more discrete with a gradual increase in the content of Zn
an indication of the presence of the orthorhombic structure due to the octahedral tilting
NCs exhibit the diffraction peaks shifted towards a higher 2
range. The shift corresponds to 0.174Â° and 0.276Â° for CsZn
increases form 0% to 15% (Supplementary Fig.Â S1). The observed peak shift is due to
the lattice contraction of as-synthesized NCs within the unit cell. The size of the lattice decreases from 5.632 Ã…
NCs and from 5.869 Ã… to 5.817 Ã… for CsZn
cations with a bigger ionic radius (119 pm) occupying the B-site of BX
cations with a smaller ionic radius (74 pm) at the same lattice site of Pb
have resided in interstitial sites, we would have observed a lattice expansion with increasing Zn
the incorporation of the smaller guest element Zn
in the octahedra of parent CsPbX
results in the reduced size of the BX
) that gives rise to the distortion and tilting of the BX
octahedra. The octahedral tilting accompanied by the change in the lattice constant lead to the increased bandgap
and blue-shifted PL emission at higher content of Zn
which will be discussed in the latter part. Interestingly, the
XRD scans do not indicate the presence of the additional peaks even after the incorporation of guest cation Zn
signifying the absence of any crystalline impurities. Furthermore, the presence of a low angle (
